Author: rokhayakebe
Content:
Guys, relax.

this guy wrote the post when most people did not know about the YC program. Give it up to him for knowing about the first funding cycle. I think a few 150 applicants knew about it.Most of people here did not hear about YC or PG until after their first demo day.

The author's opinion was the result of a rejection. If you read thoroughly,you will see that he is not dissing YC or PG. He felt that his idea was better than those funded, and frankly any entrepreneur who truly believes in his idea would think the same. Ask any YC rejects and they would show you at least 5 YC funded who they believe have an idea less creative/profitable than theirs.

That is their mistake. Most investors ideas do not mean as much as the team ability to execute against them, and YC is not different as far as that.

I am certain if you contact the author today, he would laugh and simply say "I thought I knew it all back then"

Author: tptacek
Content:
That's awesome. I keep my Mac up to date by... wait, how do I keep it up to date? Let me check, am I up to date? Well, shit, I am! How'd that happen?

Glad you have neat buttons and elegant command line tools to do it over in Ubuntu-land. Sounds like a fun project.

Author: sharpshoot
Content:
YC's been iterating on this model for 3 years now and are getting even better at identifying promising ideas and entrepreneurs. I suspect its going to take one or two more cycles to absolutely nail the model.

In terms if lessons learnt, YC has the most experience of any micro seed fund.

This is its competitive advantage.

Author: wanorris
Content:
Personally, I keep Ubuntu up to date by waiting for the little icon to pop in my tray that says I have updates, and I don't need the command line to do any part of it. It still updates all the packages I have without having to worry about looking for updates for various programs separately. I personally consider this a huge improvement over updating software by going to various websites or having several different updaters running in the background (or simply not updating your software), but perhaps you don't have non-Apple programs that need to be updated, or perhaps you don't consider this a disadvantage. Whatever works for you, works for you.

BTW, I'm fond of the command line for getting some kinds of things done, but even if you don't feel comfortable at a command line, it's a highly efficient way to tell someone how to accomplish a task (as opposed to something like Step 1: Go to the System menu, drop down the menu, expand the item labeled Administration, and click on the item labeled "Synaptic Package Manager." Step 2: click on the Search icon..., etc.). For a task that can be accomplished in one or two commands, it is often the case that there might be 10 steps involved in explaining how to navigate a GUI.

Author: notauser
Content:
Whoops, are a few basic errors here.

He has two assumptions:

- You can make a profit in the industry of your advertisers. This is a huge if, and is impacted by scale, expertise, management focus, time/maturity, branding and many other factors.

- The return on investment you can make in industry X is higher than the return on investment you can make by expanding your operations in your current industry. This could be true for social sites, where increased investment (i.e. programmer time) might not get them many more users, but they still have to compare the possible revenue to the increased profit from firing some programmers and going into maintenance mode.

These to are the main reasons why you see companies outsourcing non-core activities (like cleaning and even product development), the markup they now have to pay on the service is lower than their internal cost of capital.

Author: bretthoerner
Content:
They'd drop the _affiliates_ in NY, not all of the customers.

And to assume that the main cost to Amazon is in developer time is crazy. When the customer base suddenly starts getting taxes, the 'savings' at Amazon is lower in comparison to other competitors, and so they lose actual customers.

Content: I'll chime in with "Turn down the brightness." Monitors seem to come with it turned up too high by default - probably because it looks better on display in a store.

Author: symbiotic
Content:
I agree that social networks need better business strategies in general, but if the advertisers are making more money than the social networking sites, why make the SN site in the first place? Why not just try to beak your way into porno, gambling, credit repair (the list goes on) business and just sell adds like everyone else?

I think the answer is that we believe SN sites should be able to make more money than these other businesses. The person who figures out how to make that happen will be rich, but I don't think the answer is to just add another business onto your SN.

Author: tlrobinson
Content:
My point is really there no need for package management on Mac OS X because most Mac OS X applications don't require 30 dependencies.

A package management solution is probably better for server environments, but I don't really think it should be necessary for desktops.

Author: tptacek
Content: Yes, and in it, he claims it's easier to keep Ubuntu up to date than it is to keep a Mac up to date. To hell with empirical evidence, look at how simple that command line is! No way is my mom's MacBook that up-to-date!
